bibl.title: Chin Quock Wah vs. Henry M. White. Criminal.
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: Western District of Washington, Northern Division

div1.p: UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT, WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
In re application of CHIN QUOCK WAH and CHING HIN for Writ of Habeas Corpus. ) #2857 MEMORANDUM BRIEF.
Practically the same points are raised in both of these cases, and a brief on one can be considered as controlling the other.

In the Chin Quock Wah case it is objected that the petitioner was not allowed counsel, and he was not appraised of his right to have witnesses to appear for and in his behalf, and that he was denied the right to face his witnesses.
Covering this point the law is found in the Chinese Exclusion Act, on page 38, in the following language:

"(b) The said examination shall be separate and apart from the public, in the presence of Government officials and such other persons only as the officer in charge shall permit. All witnesses appearing on behalf of any applicant shall be fully heard."

Under this act, in the case of United States v. Williams, 190 Fed. 898, it was held that an immigrant in such cases was not entitled to be represented by counsel, and the court on page 899, uses the following language:

"There is nothing in the statute which calls for the presence of counsel at the examination of aliens preliminary to admission; nothing to indicate that it was the intent of Congress that these investigations in hundreds of thousands of cases touching the qualifications of an alien seeking to enter were to be conducted as trials in court, with counsel present to represent the alien, witnesses called to testify, and elaborate examination and cross-examination of them."

The next point raised by both cases will be found in paragraphs 3 and 4, pages 2, 3 and 4 of the petition, where it is in effect alleged that the appeal of the petitioner was not properly heard heard because J. B. Densmore, the Solicitor of the Department of Labor, made the finding while the Secretary and Assistant Secretary of Labor were present, contrary to the law in such cases provided. The point in the brief is that when an appeal is made to the Secretary of Labor, and the Secretary of Labor and his Assistant are in the office, no one but these two officers has the power to review the appeal. The attorneys for the petitioner try to sustain their position by citing Section 177, 178 and 179 Revised Statutes, 3 Fed. St. Ann. 61,62. The first of these provisions is to the effect that in case of death, resignation, absence or sickness of the head of any Department, the first or sole assistant thereof shall perform the duties of such thereof shall perform the duties of such head until a successor is appointed or until such absence or sickness shall cease.. This section and the two succeeding sections are emergency measure, meant to take care of the office on the occurence of such exigencies as the statute sets forth. It might be that if the Secretary was absent because no one was in the office with his authority the office would cease to perform its duties, but this is not meant to limit the authority of the Assistant of the Secretary and his Chief while they are in the office, because a contingency of their absence is covered by the statute this does not mean that this same statute gives a rule as to the conduct of the office when they are present.
The phase of the law covering the conduct of the office when the officers are present is found at 3 Fed. St. Ann. 58, Sec. 161 R.S., in the following language:

"Sec. 161. (Departmental Regulations) The head of each Department is authorized to prescrive regulations, not inconsistent with law, for the Government of his Department, the conduct of its officers and clerks, the distribution and performance of its business, and the custody, use, and preservation of the records, papers, and property appertaining to it."

This statute clearly gives the Secretary the power to get a subordinate to run through the record and for him to approve or disapprove of his findings. He has a clerk to assist him in any way that may seem to him proper and not in the manner that may be dictated by the attorneys for various petitioners whose cases come before him.
There is another reason this position of the attorney for petitioner is untenable. The statute provides as follows: 100 Fed. 390:

"In every case where an alien is excluded from admission into the United States under any law or treaty now existing, or hereafter made, the decision of the appropriate customs or immigration officer, if adverse to the admission of such alien, shall be final, unless reversed on appeal to the secretary of the treasury. 28 Stat. 390."
Under this statute it was held in the case of United States v. Gin Fung, 100 Fed. 389, that,

"The circuit court has no jurisdiction of habeas corpus proceedings brought by an alien excluded by the collector of the port to determine his right to land, since the collector's determination is not reviewable by the courts, buy only on appeal to the secretary of the treasury."
Again the supreme court passed on same point in the case of Lee Jung v. Patterson, 46 L. Ed. 1108-10, 186 U. S. 169, 175, in which case the court, at page 175, uses the following language:

"Under the doctrine of these cases, it is immaterial, so far as the jurisdiction of this court is concerned, Supreme Court did not express an opinion but quoted from In Re Lee Jung 102 Fed 132 -3-
whether the petitioner's appeal to the Secretary of the Treasury is heard by the Secretary in person or by a subordinate official in his department, or is heard at all."

p.del: Again the same point was passed on in teh case In Re Jem Yuen, 188 Fed. 550, 354

div1.p: Again the same point was raised In Re Lee Lung, 102 Fed. 132, 134:

"Under the doctrine of these cases, it is immaterial, so far as the jurisdiction of this court is concerned, whether the petitioner's appeal to the secretary of the treasury is heard by the secretary in person, or by a subordinate official in his department, or is heard at all. The petition for the writ is dismissed."

Even if there were anything in the contention of the attorney, the record in our opinion does not show that the Secretary did not pass on the case, thus, see the case of In Re Jem Yuen, 188 Fed. 350, 354:

"Nor do I think that the memorandum or can be considered as indicating in any way that the officer whose duty it was to hear and determine the appeal did not hear and determine it himself. It cannot be said that the head or the acting head of a department, charged with such a duty, is forbidden to have a subordinate make a preliminary report on it for his guidance. Lastly, it is complained that the Secretary of Commerce and Labor is not shown by the record to have heard and decided the appeal. I must regard the record as sufficiently showing, in the absence of any evidence to the contrary, that the appeal was heard and decided by the acting secretary. That being the case, I am justified in assuming, until the contrary appears, that the acting secretary was at the time lawfully exercising the secretary's powers. Rev. St. Secs. 177, 178, (U.S.Comp.St. 1901, p.90); Keyser v. Hitz, 133 U.S. 138, 145, 10 Sup. Ct. 290, 33 L. Ed. 531."
Respectfully submitted,
div1.ab: G. P. Fishburne, Assistant U.S. Attorney
div1.p: Received a copy of the within Memorandum Brief this day of April 1915
div1.ab: John J Sullivan Attorney for Petitioner
div1.p: No.
IN THE DISTRICT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON Northern DIVISION
In re application of Chin Quock Wah and Ching Hing for Writ of Habeas Corpus.
MEMORANDUM BRIEF.
2x
FILED IN THE U. S. District Court, Western Dist. of Washington, NORTHERN DIVISION APR7-1915
